If I understand your question correctly, you are asking pro-choice people to state what they think is the major flaw in the pro-life arguement and vice-versa. 
I think that the major flaw in the pro-life arguement is that they use slogans which may sound appealing but, on closer inspection, do not have much substance. 
For example, saying that "life is precious" may sound right but one has to analyze what one means by "life", which they mostly do not bother to do. When people hear "life is precious", people can relate because they see their own lives and those of their friends and loved ones as precious. However, the pro-life people extend that all the way back to the earliest fetus/embryo. I have seen posts of imaginary letters from that early fetus meant to elicit sympathy. This is anthropomorphising (attaching a personality where there is none) on a grand scale. They are imagining a baby with an innocent, helpless personality where there is in reality simply a growing body which will someday (around the third trimester) possess a mind, but not yet. They may have an arguement that the *potential* of that fetus is important (since, after all, we all started as fetuses) but the potentiality arguement is much less emotionally appealing and wins fewer converts than the arguement which appeals to people's imaginations in imagining a helpless, innocent, suffering baby. When it comes to the early fetus, that last arguement is an illusion - imagination is not reality. Reality is what is important.
A second, more minor, point against the pro-life arguement is that they often cannot help but mix in their views on sexual morality into their case against abortion. Many would give exceptions in the case of rape and incest because they feel sympathy toward those women. They have no sympathy toward women who chose to have sex.

title: How Abortion Should Be Dealt With?

The mother is providing a service for the child. She is a care giver, and that child needs that care to survive.
I believe quite firmly that no one should be required to provide care against their will. If they choose to provide that care, and then choose to stop providing that care, they should take all reasonable steps to ensure someone else assumes the role of care giver.
For example, if a carer at a mental home has a personal emergency and has to leave, then he should attempt to call in any on-call staff, try and get the next rostered person to come in early, or so on. After he's taken all reasonable steps, he is free of an obligation to stay.
Or if a mother can no longer handle caring for her children, she should attempt to get a friend or babysitter to care for them, or give them up to the state.
Or if a pregnant woman no longer wishes to carry her baby. Unfortunately, in that instance, it is unlikely that anyone will be in a position to assume the role of caregiver.
However, regardless of the eventual fate of the person recieving care, no person should be required, no person should be forced to provide care against their will. They should be able to abandon that person, provided they take all reasonable steps to ensure someone else assumes the role of care giver.
Needless to say, I don't consider a pregnancy to be a 'reasonable step'.

title: How Abortion Should Be Dealt With?
comment:
From Wikipedia:
Antiquity (prehistory to 476 AD)
The first recorded evidence of induced abortion is from a Chinese document which records abortions performed upon royal concubines in China between the years 500 and 515 BC. According to Chinese folklore, the legendary Emperor Shennong prescribed the use of mercury to induce abortions nearly 5000 years ago.
Abortion, along with infanticide, was common in the ancient Greco-Roman world. Numerous methods of abortion were used, "the more effective of which were exceedingly dangerous". Several common methods involved either either dosing the pregnant woman with a near-fatal amount of poison, in order to induce a miscarriage, introducing poison directly into the uterus, or prodding the uterus with one of a variety of "long needles, hooks, and knives". Unsurprisingly, these methods often led to the death of the woman, as well as the fetus.
There have been archaeological discoveries which would seem to indicate early surgical attempts at the extraction of a fetus; however, such methods are not believed to have been common, given the infrequency with which they are mentioned in ancient medical texts. Many of the methods employed in early and primitive cultures were non-surgical. Physical activities like strenuous labour, climbing, paddling, weightlifting, or diving were a common technique. Others included the use of irritant leaves, fasting, bloodletting, pouring hot water onto the abdomen, and lying on a coconut shell which had been heated.
References in classical literature
Hippocrates, the Greek physician whose famous Oath forbids abortion, nonetheless writes of having advised a dancer and prostitute who fell pregnant to jump up and down, touching her buttocks with her heels at each leap, so as to induce miscarriage. [7] Other writings attributed to him describe instruments, fashioned to dilate the cervix and curette inside of the uterus, which he used to perform an abortion upon one of his patients.
Tertullian, a 2nd and 3rd century Christian theologian, also described surgical implements which were used in a procedure reminiscent of the modern dilation and evacuation. One tool had a "nicely-adjusted flexible frame" used for dilation, an "annular blade" used to curette, and a "blunted or covered hook" used for extraction. The other was a "copper needle or spike". He attributed ownership of such items to Hippocrates, Asclepiades, Erasistratus, Herophilus, and Soranus.
Tertullian's description is prefaced as being used in cases in which abnormal positioning of the fetus in the womb would endanger the life of the pregnant women. Saint Augustine, in Enchiridion, makes passing mention of surgical procedures being performed to remove fetuses which have expired in utero. [10] Aulus Cornelius Celsus, a 1st century Roman encyclopedist, offers an extremely detailed account of a procedure to extract an already dead fetus in his only surviving work, De Medicina.
In Book 9 of Refutation of all Heresies, Saint Hippolytus of Rome, another Christian theologian of the 3rd century, wrote of women tightly binding themselves around the middle so as to "expel what was being conceived."
Soranus, a 2nd century Greek physician, provided some rather detailed suggestions in his work Gynecology. He recommended that women wishing to abort their pregnancies should engage in violent exercise, energetic jumping, carrying heavy objects, and riding animals. Diuretics, emmenagogues, enemas, fasting, and bloodletting, were also prescribed, although Soranus advised against the use of sharp instruments to induce miscarriage due to the risk of organ perforation.
